text: <!channel> and specifically people working on compass-backend, I hope to clarify something quickly: *do not* merge the test branch into your feature branches. The test branch by design has lots of unreviewed code from different people in it, and if it gets merged into a feature branch, it will be very difficult to review that branch and merge into dev cleanly when the time comes.
Similarly, when starting a feature branch, branching off dev is generally best practice. Starting a feature branch from test will bring up the same issues above.
Thanks for bringing that up, Jenny!
Yes thanks Jenny! Good call out
have we used or do we use pull requests at all?
as of now, we don’t and we haven’t, but it’s something worth discussing
it could be worthwhile in this case especially with respect to tracking a set of changes made on particular branch, and any discussion that might happen around those changes
definitely. It was considered as part of the code review process at the beginning and then I decided against it. It seems that decision is worth revisiting.
i’m coming from a place that was very PR intensive so it’s habit for me at this point, but i appreciate that you wanted to keep the process as streamlined as possible to begin with

<@U167FL70V> <@U0261PCRQ> so far team backend has not created PRs but when it’s time for a code review, share the like to the comparison page. For example <https://github.com/adidasFuture/compass-backend/compare/dev...thirdparty?expand=1>
so starting to do real pull requests could make sense
ooh that’s a handy way of doing things as well. since we’re in a process review and streamlining phase we could try a few with PRs to see how we feel
<@U02613K0X> and <@U02HAJ6JF> ^^ maybe for the next feature(s) you work on?
and i’ll do the same once i get to the point of actually contributing something useful
Thanks for testing that out, Leia, Joshua, and Jenny! I’d love to hear how that goes and see if it would be beneficial to roll out to the whole team.
